Fig 7 Coordination environment engineering of transition metal doped phthalocyanine single-atom catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction reaction: A DFT study Fang Xu Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Zhenzhen Wang Investigation Validation Zhiyi Liu Investigation Validation Aling Ma Investigation Validation Dandan Wu Methodology Investigation Fanghui Wu Funding acquisition Hong Xu Conceptualization Methodology Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ Guohong Fan Resources Funding acquisition Writing – review & editing ⁎ School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Anhui University of Technology, Maanshan, Anhui 243002, PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Anhui University of Technology Maanshan Anhui 243002 PR China School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Anhui University of Technology, Maanshan, Anhui 243002, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Developing of low cost and highly efficient electrocatalysts for carbon dioxide reduction (CRR) is becoming a research hotspot in both theoretical and experimental studies. In this work, we systematically investigated by first-principles calculations the electrocatalytic properties of transition-metal-anchored Phthalocyanine (Pc) monolayers with and without different heteroatom modifications, named TM-Pc and TM-X-Pc (TM = Sc∼ Zn, X = B, C, N, O, and S), respectively. The results show Cr-Pc, Mn-Pc, Sc-O-Pc, Cr-O-Pc, Mn-O-Pc, Fe-O-Pc, and Co-O-Pc exhibited excellent catalytic performance and high selectivity for CRR. The origin of catalytic activity analysis indicated the binding energy of intermediates Eb(*OH) and Eb(*CHO) serve as the descriptors for the catalytic performance of TM-X-Pc. Further comparative analyses showed that choosing appropriate coordination atoms is beneficial for adjusting the catalytic activity. The work suggests that the heteroatoms modified TM-X-Pc monolayer has high potential application as high-performance CRR catalyst and provides valuable theoretical guidance for designing efficient CRR catalysts. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 electrocatalytic reduction reaction Phthalocyanine Single-atom catalyst Density functional theory Electrocatalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Excessive emissions of CO2 are seriously damaging the global environment, causing the increase of global average temperature, rise of sea level, acidification of ocean, and pollution of atmospheric [1–3]. Among several solutions to reduce excessive carbon dioxide emissions, turning CO2 into valuable hydrocarbons is regarded as one of the most promising methods. Specifically, chemical conversion, biological transformation, photocatalytic and electrocatalytic reduction could convert CO2 to high-value chemicals [4–7]. In particular, electrocatalytic CO2 reduction reaction (CRR) possesses the advantages of low cost, environmental friendliness, mild reaction conditions, and controllable process, which became a research hot spot in both theoretical and experimental studies [8,9]. However, the remain shortcomings of low reaction rate and poor selectivity of CRR still severely limit its practical application. So, developing of low cost and highly efficient electrocatalyst is still urgently required by researchers. Single-atom catalysts (SACs) are generally catalysts loaded with isolated metal atoms as active catalytic centers. Due to the dispersion of active sites at the atomic scale, SACs possess multiple advantages, such as unique electronic structure, large surface free energy, strong metal-support interactions, and maximum atom utilization [10,11]. Hence, since Zhang et al. first reported that Pt single-atom loaded in FeOX exhibits excellent catalytic performance for CO oxidation [12]. SACs have become widely used in various electrochemical reactions such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen reduction/evolution reaction (ORR/OER), and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR) [13–25]. Particularly, tetra-N-doped metal-coordinate two-dimensional SACs(M-N4) are proven to be effective electrocatalysts for CRR [26–34]. In the designing and pursuing of efficient SACs, the electron acceptor-donor effects induced by the different coordination environments of SACs could precisely regulate the electronic structure of the central atom, which is crucial for adjusting and enhancing the catalytic performance. Thus, doping with heteroatom in SACs with different electronegativities is one of the most effective strategies for high-performance CRR electrocatalyst [35–40]. In particular, the local electronic density of the catalytic active center sites can be tuned with the B, C, O or S atom to replace the N coordination atom of M-N4 center, which can result in superior electrocatalytic performance than the traditional M-N4 center. For example, wang and co-works reported that asymmetrically coordinated IrN3O catalysts can be applied to the formic acid oxidation reaction (FAOR) with high-performance, in which the O doping can splits and downshifts the Ir 5d orbitals and modulate the binding strength of the key intermediates [41]. Song et al. designed CuN3O/C as a CRR catalyst, and the theoretical and experimental results both showed excellent selectivity and activity [42]. Guo et al. reported Sn-N3O1 can be designed as a highly efficient catalyst for reducing CO2, both experimental results and theoretical calculations suggest that the asymmetric atomic interface decreases the energy barrier of the rate-determining step for CO formation while increasing the energy barrier for the generation of *OCHO and inhibiting the production of HCOOH [43]. Zhou examined the catalytic performance of 30 TMNxO4-x-HTP monolayers based on theoretical calculations, of which RhN3O1 HTP serves as an efficient bifunctional catalyst for HER and OER. Meanwhile, previous study showed that changing the local coordination environment of TM-N/O in the catalyst could adjust the adsorption strength between the intermediate and metal active center to influence the catalytic performance [44]. Research also indicates that S-doping can effectively enhance the ORR activity of CoN4 with an overpotential as low as 0.25 V. Further analysis of the electronic structure revealed that the S-doping activates the N atoms and regulates the energy gap of the original CoN4, leading to the enhancement of the ORR activity [45]. In addition, boron atom is also widely used as the coordinating atoms in SACs to tune the catalytic activity, which can effectively coordinate with the substrate and bind with the intermediate to improve catalytic performance. For example, Liu et al. reported the single atomic Fe sites anchored on B and N co-doped carbon showed excellent CRR activity, achieving the highest Faradaic efficiency of ∼94 % at −0.7 V relative to the reversible hydrogen electrode, with substantially improved performance compared to the B-free sample [46]. Our previous study on TM and B-atom co-doped graphyne (GY) as CRR catalysts show that the synergistic interaction between B and Mn atoms decreases the energy barrier at the critical step, resulting in the excellent catalytic performance of MnB1-GY (UL = −0.21 V) [47]. Phthalocyanine (Pc) is a macrocyclic organic-conjugated molecule with a unique π-electron structure that consists of the imine group linked to four isoindoles [48]. Metal atoms could coordinate with four pyrrole nitrogen atoms to form transition metal phthalocyanine (TM-Pc) complexes by the natural cavities. Recently, several 2D TM phthalocyanine monolayers (TM-Pc, TM = Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn) have been synthesized experimentally with applications in gas sensors and electrocatalysis [49–54]. For example, Choi et al. developed carbon-supported Fe-Pc films as non-precious metal catalysts for oxygen reduction reactions. Their results indicate that the sample with heat treatment possess excellent ORR performance, with high selectivity (>98 %) towards the efficient 4 electron reduction [55]. Li and coworkers prepared the Co-Pc polymeric supported on carbon nanotubes by template-directed polymerization. With combined experimental and computational calculations this study indicates that Co-Pc could reduce CO2 into CO as high-performance electrocatalysts [50]. Yang et al. systematically investigate the CO2 electrocatalytic performance of TM-Pc monolayers as single-atom catalysts with density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The result revealed that formic acid (HCOOH) is the main reduction product of CrPc and MnPc with overpotentials of 0.043 and 0.017 V, respectively [56]. Huang and coworkers developed a range of NRR catalysts by doping 3d, 4d, and 5d TMs onto a Pc monolayer. Among them, Mo-Pc and Tc-Pc were identified as the most promising catalysts for their superior stability and low onset potential [57]. Co-Pc monolayers can also adsorb toxic gasses selectively and are unaffected by the water in the air, which is a promising gas-sensing material for toxic gas detection [58]. The above studies manifests the widely used applications of TM-Pc monolayers. However, as a typical TM-N4 SAC, whether and how the catalytic performance of TM-Pc monolayers can be tuned by introducing the heteroatoms to modify the coordination environment of TM-Pc? Is there a rule on the effect of the doped heteroatom species on the CRR catalytic performance? There is still a lack of relevant research for these important questions. In view of this, we systematically investigated the performance of TM anchored Pc monolayers co-doped with different heteroatoms as CRR catalysts, called TM-Pc and TM-X-Pc (TM = Sc∼ Zn, X = B, O, S and C), respectively. The stability of the systems is assessed by calculating the Ef and U d i s s , in which Sc-B-Pc, Ti-B-Pc, Sc-Pc, and S-doping systems (TM-S-Pc) are screened out due to instability. The remaining 27 systems were then studied in detail and analyzed for CRR catalytic performance. The results revealed that the seven candidates, Cr-Pc, Mn-Pc, Sc-O-Pc, Cr-O-Pc, Mn-O-Pc, Fe-O-Pc, and Co-O-Pc, performed excellent catalytic performance (ΔGmax < 0.5 eV). Analysis of the catalytic activity origin showed that binding energy of intermediates Eb(*OH) and Eb(*CHO) can be regarded as a descriptor for screening efficient CRR catalysts. Further investigation indicated that modifying the coordinating environment of the active center by changing the doping atom is an effective way to tune the catalytic performance. Therefore, this study provides an effective method for designing highly active CRR catalysts. 2 Computational details All spin-polarized density functional theory (DFT) calculations in this paper were performed with the Dmol3 program [59,60]. Gibbs free energy calculations were carried out in Atomic Simulation Environment 3.18.1 (ASE) [61]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) function of generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was used to describe the exchange-correlation energy [62,63]. Considering the interaction between the catalyst and the reaction intermediates, the Grimme method was employed for dispersion correction [64]. The DFT semi-pseudopotential (DSPP) approach was used to study the core atoms, which replaces the nuclear electrons with a single effective potential and incorporates the particular relativistic correction [65]. To ensure the accuracy of calculation results, the convergence precision of energy, force, and displacement is set to 1.0 × 10−5 Ha, 2.0 × 10−3 Ha·Å −1 and 5.0 × 10−3 Å, respectively, and the double numerical plus polarized (DNP) atomic orbital basis set with a global orbital cutoff radius of 5.0 Å is adopted for all systems. In the calculation, 3 × 3 × 1 and 6 × 6 × 1 Monkhorst-Pack k-point grids were applied for structural optimization and electronic properties calculation, respectively [66]. Since the CRR commonly occurs within the solvent environment, we also set a conductor-like shielding model (COSMO) with a dielectric constant of 78.54 [67]. Based on the computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model proposed by Norskov, the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG) for each electron-proton transfer step in the CRR electrocatalytic processes was computed: (1) Δ G = Δ E + Δ E ZPE − T Δ S + Δ ∫ C P d T + Δ G pH + Δ G U where Δ E is the DFT total energy difference between the two adsorption systems, T is the reaction temperature (T = 298.15 K), Δ E ZPE is the zero-point energy difference, and Δ S represents the correction of the entropy value. Δ ∫ C P d T is the enthalpy correction for molecular vibrational contributions. Δ G pH is the free energy correction for H + concentration, in which Δ G pH = 2 . 303 k B T × pH , where kB is Boltzmann's constant, and pH = 0 in this study. Δ G U is the effect of applied electrode potentials U on the free energy, with definition of Δ G pH = neU , and n is the total number of proton-electron pairs transferred [68]. For assessing electrocatalytic activity, the limiting potential ( U L ) is calculated with equation: (2) U L = − Δ G max / e where Δ G max is the maximum Gibbs free energy change in the reduction pathway. The binding energy E b ( * C x H y O z ) of CRR intermediates on catalysts is defined as the following relation: (3) E b ( * C x H y O z ) = E * C x H y O z − E * − x E C − y E H − z E O where E * C x H y O z represents the total energy of the intermediates adsorbed on the catalyst, E * is the energy of the corresponding catalyst, x, y, and z are the numbers of C, H, and O atoms in the intermediate. The energies of C, H, and O atoms are obtained from the energies of CO, H2, and H2O, respectively [69–71]. To investigate the stability of the studies systems, the formation energy (Ef) of the TM-X-Pc structure with different anchored TM and heteroatom modifications is calculated by the following equation: (4) E f ( T M − P c ) = E T M − P c − E P c − E T M (5) E f ( T M − X − P c ) = E T M − X − P c − E P c − E T M − μ X + μ N where E T M − P c , E T M − X − P c , and E P c denote the total energy of TM-Pc, TM-X-Pc, and original Pc, respectively, μ N and μ X represent the chemical potential of the N atom and the doped atom (X = B, C, O, and S), and E T M is the energy of the TM atom in the stable bulk structure. The dissolution potential is calculated by the equation: (6) U d i s s = U d i s s 0 ( m e t a l , b u l k ) − E f / n e where U d i s s 0 ( m e t a l , b u l k ) and n are the standard dissolution potential for different TM in the bulk structure and the number of transferred electrons during dissolution. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structure and stability Fig. 1 a shows the original Pc monolayer structure with each unit cell containing 20 C atoms, 8 N atoms, and 4 H atoms, in which all atoms are in one plane without any buckling in the structure. The optimized lattice constant is 10.66 Å, and the structure exhibits the P4/MMM space group, which matches well with the experiment and other researches [58,72–76]. Considering the interaction between Pc monolayers, the vacuum interlayer distance of 20 Å is set to avoid interlayer interaction. After anchoring the TM atoms (TM = Sc∼Zn) into the hole of Pc monolayer, the structure remains coplanarity without significant change. However, when a heteroatom X (X = B, O, or S) is doped to replace the coordinating N atom connected directly with the TM center (Fig. 1b), part of the TM-B-Pc structures are slightly distorted, with the lattice parameter change negligible. The specific TM-X-Pc structure model is shown in Figure S1∼S4 of the supporting information. Structural stability is one of the prerequisites to judge whether the catalyst is promising for the target application. Therefore, we first calculated the formation energy (Ef) of the TM-X-Pc structure with Eqs. (4) and (5) to investigate the structural stability. According to the definition, Ef < 0 indicates that the catalyst shows good thermodynamic stability. As shown in Fig. 2 , the results reveal that TM-Pc presents excellent stability with the Ef are all negative, ranging from −3.587 to −6.163 eV. When replacing the coordinating N atom with B, the value of Ef for TM-B-Pc increases but remains stable in the range of −2.606 to −3.918 eV. The O-doped system (TM-O-Pc) displayed the best thermodynamic stability with a more negative Ef value from −4.675 to −7.197 eV. However, the Ef of most TM-S-Pc structures is positive which indicates they are poorly thermodynamically stable. Doping with different heteroatom thus can lead to structure with different thermodynamically stability. The origin of the discrepancy is the different species of heteroatom employed for doping, in which the introduction of O atoms as coordinating atom can improve the stability of the structure. Furthermore, since the CRR occurs in the solvent environment, dissolution potential ( U d i s s ) is another significant parameter to assess realistic electrochemical stability, which is calculated by Eq. (6) . The catalyst is stable in acidic conditions when U d i s s > 0 V. As shown in Fig. 2d, the value of U d i s s for TM-S-Pc system is negative which indicates electrochemical instability under a solvent environment. Also, Sc-B-Pc, Ti-B-Pc and Sc-Pc system possess negative Udiss value. Therefore, these above systems are precluded owing to their poor stability. The above analysis on the structural stability also reveals that doping with O atom can improve the structure stability of TM-Pc electrocatalyst. In addition, we conducted the Hirsheld charge analysis on the remaining 27 candidates and summarized the results in Table S2∼S4. The result shows that TMs are all positively charged in the original TM-Pc monolayer, and the four surrounding nitrogen atoms are negatively charged with almost the same value, implying that TM atoms transfer electrons to four coordinating nitrogen atoms uniformly. When an O atom is introduced to replace one of the N atoms, the charge on the TM atom of TM-O-Pc slightly fluctuates, and the charge distribution of the four coordination atoms is no longer balanced, with the O atom receiving fewer electrons. The donated electrons of TM atoms are decreased obviously in the TM-B-Pc, in which Ni atom donates electrons of only 0.051 e. For the TM-B-Pcs, except that the B atoms in Ni-B-Pc donates electrons, the doped B atoms in the other seven candidates get electrons, and the other three coordination N atoms still accumulate electrons. The charge distribution balance between coordination atoms and TM atom is disrupted completely in TM-X-Pc. Hence, the local electron density of the metal center can change by adjusting the coordination environment with introduction of heteroatoms, and the difference in electronegativity of doping atom have different effects on the charge distribution of the active center. Then, we further investigated the CRR catalytic performance of the remaining 27 TM-X-Pc models after thermodynamic and electrochemical stability screening. 3.2 CO2 adsorption The capture of CO2 on the surface is the fundamental prerequisite in the CRR process. Therefore, we first calculate the adsorption energy of CO2 (Eads) on the TM-X-Pc which is defined as: E ads = E total − − E slab − − E C O 2 , where E total , E slab , E C O 2 are the total energy of TM-X-Pc with adsorbed CO2, the energy of the TM-X-Pc monolayer, and the energy of CO2 in the gas phase, respectively. The detailed optimized geometry and calculation results are summarized in Figure S5∼7 and S8 respectively. The adsorption of CO2 on the original TM-Pc is a spontaneous process with the Eads all negative, ranging from −0.408 to −1.287 eV. The Eads of the TM-O-Pc system fluctuates slightly but is still all negative from −0.417 to −1.357 eV. When a B atom is introduced to replace one of the N atoms, TM-B-Pcs showed a more pronounced change in CO2 adsorption capacity, in which V-B-Pc, Cr-B-Pc, Co-B-Pc, and Zn-B-Pc exhibited Eads of −1.783 eV, −1.425 eV, −1.484 eV, and −1.177 eV, which could perform CO2 capture well. All these results suggest that 27 TM-X-Pc models could trap CO2 spontaneously, and the different species of heteroatom employed for doping can influence the activation of CO2 to various degrees. 3.3 CO2 reduction reaction The hydrogenation reduction of CO2 can produce various C1, C2, and C3 compounds. It is hard to cause the CC coupling between reaction intermediates due to only one active metal site in TM-X-Pc, which is required to produce the C2 and C3 products. Therefore, this work considers only the generation of C1 products (i.e., CO, HCOOH, HCHO, CH3OH, and CH4). Fig. 3 a shows the CO2 hydrogenation pathway to different products, and the change in free energy (∆G) along different pathway is calculated to determine the minimum energy pathway. Fig. S9∼S11 and Table S5∼S34 display the detailed free energy profiles and related values for reaction intermediates. CO is the two-electron product of CRR, and the reduction process involves two proton-electron pairs transfer with the route: * + C O 2 → * C O 2 →*COOH→*+CO +H2O. Fig. 3b shows the limiting potential for CO generation and the corresponding rate-determining step. For the TM-Pc system, the first hydrogenation step of CO2: * C O 2 →*COOH, is the RDS for Ti-Pc, Mn-Pc, Ni-Pc, Cu-Pc, and Zn-Pc. For these systems, except for Mn-Pc which has a low reaction energy barrier of 0.488 eV, the reaction energy barrier of others exceeds 1 eV. For V-Pc, Cr-Pc, Fe-Pc, and Co-Pc, the RDSs are the desorption and production of CO, with free energy increases of 0.764 eV, 0.406 eV, 0.534 eV, and 0.639 eV correspondingly. *COOH→*+CO +H2O is the RDS of the former six TM-O-Pc (TM = Sc∼ Fe) candidates, while for the last four systems the generation of *COOH is the RDS, where Cr-O-Pc, Mn-O-Pc, and Co-O-Pc exhibit good catalytic performance with ΔGmax of 0.428 eV, 0.419 eV, and 0.446 eV, respectively. While for the TM-B-Pc, except that the RDS of Ni-B-Pc is * C O 2 →*COOH, the RDS of the remaining seven systems are all *COOH→*+CO +H2O, and most of the energy barriers are higher than 1 eV, which means that CO is difficult to desorb from the catalyst surface. Among them, Cr-Pc exhibited the best catalytic performance (UL = −0.406 V), which is superior to the reported Cu cluster anchored Cu3@C2N(−0.67 V) and Cu3@GY(−0.50 V) catalysts. [77,78]. Similar with the production of CO, the production of HCOOH also involves two hydrogenation steps, with the difference is the H proton adsorbs on the C atom at the first hydrogenation step, and its route is * + C O 2 → * C O 2 →*OCHO→*+HCOOH. As can be seen in Fig. 3c, the RDS for the first four TM-Pc (TM = Ti∼ Mn) is the desorption of HCOOH, and for the remaining five TM-Pc systems is the production of *OCHO, among which the Δ G max of Mn-Pc is lowest (0.463 eV). For all TM-B-Pc, the RDS is consistent with the same hydrogenation step of *OCHO→*+HCOOH, and the corresponding energy barriers are more than 1 eV, even the increase of 2.124 eV in free energy is observed on Zn-B-Pc. In addition, the Δ G max step of Fe-O-Pc, Co-O-Pc, Ni-O-Pc, and Cu-O-Pc is * C O 2 →*OCHO, and the HCOOH desorption and formation step are the RDS of the remaining six TM-O-Pc. It is worth noting that although the whole pathway and RDS are the same, the energy barrier of Fe-O-Pc is 0.309 eV, which is far lower than the original Fe-Pc (0.629 eV), exhibiting the best catalytic performance, even lower than Cu-GY (1.14 eV), Cu-Cr@C2N (0.90 eV) and Cu-Mn@C2N (1.14 eV). [79,80]. As a four-electron product, the reduction pathway for HCHO is * + C O 2 → * C O 2 → * COOH → * CO → * CHO / * COH → * + HCHO . The H + could adsorb on the C atom or O atom with *CO further reduced, so there are two possible reduction routes for HCHO production. According to the complete pathway diagrams, the energy barrier required for the generation of *CHO is much lower than *COH, which means the hydrogenation of *CO to *CHO is more preferred. As Fig. 3d displayed, the RDS for Co-Pc,Sc-O-Pc,Ti-O-Pc,Mn-O-Pc,Fe-O-Pc, and the total 8 TM-B-Pcs are the desorption and production of HCHO, for V-Pc,Cr-Pc,Fe-Pc and V-O-Pc are * CO → * CHO , and for the remaining 10 TM-X-Pc systems are the generation of *COOH. In comparison, the catalytic performance of the pristine Ni, Cu, and Zn anchored Pc is significantly improved after introducing the O coordinating atom, which keeps the same RDS for the reaction but the corresponding energy barrier is reduced effectively. However, when modifying the coordination environment with B atoms doping, the ∆Gmax steps of TM-B-Pcs are all * CHO → * + HCHO . For all the TM-B-Pcs, except for Ni-B-Pc which possesses the lowest ∆Gmax of 0.751 eV, the high energy barrier for this step of other B modified TM-PC systems (large than 0.751 eV) indicate the *CHO will continue hydrogenation to other intermediates involved in the reaction instead of producing HCHO on TM-B-Pcs. Among the 27 candidates, O atom modified systems present high performance, among which Mn-O-Pc exhibits the best catalytic performance with a limiting potential of only −0.337 V. In the further reduction of *CHO, it prefers to continue the reaction by hydrogenating to *CHOH or *OCH2 instead of HCHO due to the high energy barrier required for HCHO formation. As a deep six-electron transfer product of reduction, the pathway for CH3OH production is * + C O 2 → * C O 2 → * COOH → * CO → * CHO → * CHOH / * OC H 2 → * C H 2 OH / * OC H 3 → * + C H 3 OH . As can be seen from Figure S12a that Fe-O-Pc boasted the lowest Δ G max value among all 27 candidates. Again, the O modified TM-Pc show better performance than other heteroatom modified systems. To reveal the underline reason for the better performance of O modified system than other heteroatom modified systems. We then focused the comparative analysis on reducing CO2 to CH3OH for Fe-Pc, Fe-B-Pc, and Fe-O-Pc. As shown in Fig. 4 a, the free energy of Fe-Pc along the reduction pathway ( * COOH → * CO → * CHO ) exhibits a trend of decreasing and then increasing, with the highest energy barrier of the reaction being the formation of *CHO by *CO hydrogenation (0.721 eV); the free energy fluctuation is remarkably weaker on Fe-O-Pc, with the RDS changing to * CHO → * OC H 2 which has the free energy uphill of only 0.324 eV; while the trend of energy change in this route remains the same for Fe-B-Pc, but the deep reduction pathway is changed, with the generation of CH3OH being the highest energy uphill step of 1.130 eV. Similarly, after doping with O atom on Ni-Pc, Cu-Pc, and Zn-Pc, their catalytic performance is enhanced by lowering the step with the highest energy barrier. Compared with Fe-Pc, the O heteroatom modification in Fe-O-Pc provide with the best coordinating environment for anchored TM, achieve the suitable binding strength for *CO and *CHO (weaker binding strength for *CO and stronger binding with *CHO). This can thus reduce the energy barrier for * CO → * CHO , leading to the RDS being * CHO → * OC H 2 , and finally reaching the best catalytic activity. However, the B heteroatom modification in Fe-B-Pc produce stronger binding strength for both *CO and *CHO (too strong for *CO), unable to the reach the low limiting potential for the whole reaction. CH4 is the main eight-electron product of CRR. There are two possible reduction pathways for CH4: * + C O 2 → * C O 2 → * COOH → * CO → * CHO → * CHOH / * OC H 2 → * OC H 3 → * O + C H 4 → * OH → * H 2 O , the difference is that the hydrogenation of *CHO to generate *CHOH or *OCH2. When three H atoms and one O atom completely saturate the C atom in *OCH3, the subsequent proton-electron transfer to *OCH3 results in the CO bond breaking and the desorption of CH4 from the catalytic surface. The complete reduction reaction ends when the *O continues to hydrogenate until it produces *H2O. Figure S12b depicts the limiting potential of 27 candidates for reduction of CO2 to CH4. The energy required for RDS of TM-Pc is below 0.500 eV only for Cr-Pc and Mn-Pc; the limit potential of Ni-B-Pc which exhibit the best catalytic performance in TM-B-Pcs is −0.606 V which exceeds −0.500 V; however, five candidates present excellent catalytic performance (∆Gmax < 0.500 eV) when the coordination environment is modified by the O atom. Fig. 4b demonstrates in detail the reaction process of CH4 production on Cr-Pc, Mn-Pc, Sc-O-Pc, Cr-O-Pc, Mn-O-Pc, Fe-O-Pc, and Co-O-Pc. Among these, the RDS of Cr-Pc is * CO → * CHO (ΔG = 0.415 eV), while on Cr-O-Pc it changes to * C O 2 → * COOH (ΔG = 0.380 eV); the RDS of the Mn-doped catalyst changes from * C O 2 → * COOH (ΔG = 0.488 eV) to * CO → * CHO (ΔG = 0.432 eV) after replacing with the O coordinating atom. The above results mean that for Cr-Pc and Mn-Pc, introducing the O atom could change the RDS and reduce the corresponding energy barrier, thus enhancing the catalytic performance. In particular, Fe-O-Pc exhibited the highest catalytic activity (UL = −0.324 V), comparable to or even lower than some reported catalysts. For example, the single TM (TM = Mn, Fe, Ni, Cu, Mo, Pt) atom anchored GDY (from −0.43 V to −1.07 V) [81], GDY modified with single boron atoms (−0.60 V) [82], Cu, Fe and Cr trimetallic clusters supported on GY (−0.39∼ −0.56 V) [78,83], Co2 N@Gra (−0.37 V) [84], Cu/Fe-NC (−0.51 V) [85], FeFe-grafiN6 (−0.61 V) [86], N6V4-AgCr (−0.38 V) [87], CuCr/C2N (−0.37 V) [88], and MnCu@2SV (−0.64 V) [89]. Moreover, the UL values obtained from this process can be used to select the target products for CRR for different catalysts, and Fig. 4c summarizes the detailed results. Cr-Pc, Fe-O-Pc, Co-Pc, and Cr-O-Pc exhibited the highest catalytic activities for reducing CO2 to CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, and CH4 respectively. And also, to summarize, the O heteroatom modification in TM-Pc can generally provide with the more suitable coordinating environment for the adsorbed intermediates among the studied candidates, leading to the high activity of TM-O-PC for CRR than the other heteroatom modification. 3.4 CRR vs HER CRR generally occurs in a solvent environment, and the TM atoms anchored in the catalyst inevitably react with the proton in the solution, so there is a competitive relationship between HER and CRR. The capture and activation of CO2 on the surface is the initial step in the CRR process. The activation of CO2 is not only a key step to achieve the efficient performance but also necessary to inhibit the HER side reaction. We calculate and compare the Gibbs free energy for adsorption of *CO2 and *H on catalysts (Figure 5a∼c). Reaction with low energy barriers occurs more preferentially and occupies the active site. The system below the diagonal line shows better selectivity for CRR, while above the diagonal line indicates the HER is more preferential. Except for Co-Pc on which the *H adsorption is preferred, all original TM-Pc exhibit promising CRR selectivity; adsorption of *CO2 at the TM site is favored on ten TM-O-Pcs; although TM-B-Pc could activate CO2 molecules effectively, but it shows HER preference and cannot suppress the competing side reactions. In addition, we further calculated the difference of limiting potential between CRR and HER to assess the selectivity (Fig. S13 and Fig. 5 d). The positive potential difference implies the high selectivity of the catalyst for CRR by definition. We set the difference on Cu (211) catalyst (−0.65 V) as a benchmark which is recognized as the best CRR catalyst in experiments [90]. Except for Co-Pc and Zn-O-Pc, the remaining candidates are more favorable for the reduction of CO2 than HER, which exhibit high CRR selectivity compared to the pure copper catalysts. 3.5 Activity origin One determinant factor of the catalytic performance is the ability of the catalysts to bind with different CRR intermediates, which is originated from the electronic properties of the catalyst to adjust directly the binding energy of intermediates [4,47,91–95]. Therefore, we calculated and analyzed the binding energies of different intermediates on TM-X-Pcs. Considering the complexity of the CRR pathway and the variety of possible intermediates, we performed computational analyses only for reaction intermediates in the CH4 generation pathway. Meanwhile, the intermediates are divided into oxygen- and carbon-bonded intermediates according to the connection mode connected to the catalyst. The binding energies of *CHO and *OH intermediates are widely used descriptors for catalytic activity in previous reports [6,96–100]. Therefore, we chose Eb(*CHO) and Eb(*OH) as the descriptors to analyze the linear relationship between the binding energies of the carbon-bonded and oxygen-bonded intermediates, respectively. As present in Fig. 6 ab, Eb(*CHO) and Eb(*COOH) exhibit a strong positive proportional linear relationship (R2 = 0.927) among carbon-bonded intermediates; all oxygen-bonded intermediates show a great linear relationship with Eb(*OH), with the strongest proportionality for Eb(*OCH3), and Eb(*O) (R2 = 0.998, R2 = 0.921 respectively). A good linear relationship between the binding energies of different intermediates indicates that the corresponding elementary reactions are also restricted. Therefore, we further performed the linear fitting for the relationship between Gibbs free energy change of different elementary reactions and the binding energies of Eb(*CHO) and Eb(*OH). The results are summarized in Figure 6 cd, ΔG ( * COOH → * + CO + H 2 O ) and ΔG( * CHOH → * + HCHO ) presents an inverse proportional linear relationship, the more negative binding energy of the *CHO intermediate on the substrate will result in a higher energy barrier to overcome for the production of CO or HCHO, which means that the reaction will continue to generate other products by hydrogen reduction of *CHO. * C O 2 → * + COOH and * CO → * CHO act as common RDSs and the relationship are also calculated. It is clear that the reaction energy change of both increases with increasing Eb(*CHO), which indicates the two hydrogenation steps are more advantageous when the more negative binding energy is. Whether more negative Eb(*CHO) leads to better catalyst performance? Therefore, we carry out an analysis for the relation of ΔG with Eb(*OH) for other elementary reactions. As Eb(*OH) increases, the production of CH3OH from *OCH3 or generation of *H2O from *OH is more beneficial, and the ΔG ( * OC H 2 → * OC H 3 ) and ΔG ( * OC H 3 → * O + C H 4 ) rise simultaneously. Combining Figure S12b and the RDS of each system, it is evident that the energy barrier of conventional RDS decreases as the binding strength of adsorbed intermediates increases, but the step with the highest energy barrier changes and the overall catalytic performance of the catalyst is limited. Then, the UL(CH4) as a function of Eb(*CHO) is investigated (Figure S14). The relationship between the two shows a volcanic shape, which indicates that the system obtains better catalytic performance in the range of −1.000∼ −1.600 eV for Eb(*CHO). Among 27 candidates, Cr-O-Pc, Mn-O-Pc, Fe-O-Pc, Co-O-Pc, Cr-Pc, and Mn-Pc systems are close to the apex and show excellent catalytic performance. 3.6 Comparison of coordination environments To further explore the effect of the doping atoms species on the catalyst activity of the active center of the catalyst and how it modulates the catalytic performance, we then dedicate on the coordinating atoms and compare the catalytic performance of TM-PC with one of the N coordinating atoms modified by atoms with different electronegativity from B, C, O atoms (TM-B-Pc, TM-C-Pc, TM-Pc and TM-O-Pc). For TM-C-Pcs, we constructed Cr-C-Pc, Mn-C-Pc, and Fe-C-Pc models with one of the N coordinating atoms modified by the C atom and performed the same CRR path analysis. Figure S15 shows the detailed reaction process, and Fig. 7 a summarizes the free energy profiles for CO2 reduction to CH4 over the three systems. There are differences in the reaction pathways, with Cr-C-Pc beneficial to generate *OCH2 by *CHO hydrogenation and Mn-C-Pc and Fe-C-Pc preferring the formation of *CHOH. Across the whole reaction pathway, the step with the highest free energy change for Cr-C-Pc and Fe-C-Pc is * CO → * CHO with barriers of 0.498 eV and 0.745 eV, respectively. The RDS for Mn-C-Pc is * CHOH → * OC H 3 with an energy barrier of 0.569 eV. Comparing the limiting potentials of 12 catalysts to generate CH4 (TM-B-Pc, TM-C-Pc, TM-Pc and TM-O-Pc, TM=Fe, Cr, Mn), the results indicate that the catalytic performance of the catalysts gradually improves with the electronegativity of the heteroatoms increasing from the B atom to the O atom, except for Fe-B-Pc in Fe-X-Pc that breaks the rule. We calculated the projected density of state (PDOS) of *CHO adsorbed on 12 candidates (Figure S16∼S18). The TM-d orbitals in Cr-B-Pc, Mn-B-Pc, and Fe-B-Pc overlap significantly near the Fermi energy level with the C(*CHO)-p or B-p orbitals, which is consistent with the strong adsorption of *CHO on these catalysts. However, as the doping atom changes from B to C, N, or O, the overlap between the p orbital of the heteroatom and the C-p orbital in *CHO gradually decreases, and the overlap with the TM-d orbital gradually shifts to the region below the Fermi level. Furthermore, we computed the relationship between the amount of charge carried on CHO (QCHO) and Eb(*CHO). As shown in Fig. 7c, the relationship between QCHO and Eb(*CHO) can form a volcano-type curve. When the CHO species receives or donates a certain number of electrons, the *CHO binds more stably to the catalyst. According to the above discussion, there is a volcano-type curve between Eb(*CHO) and UL(CH4), and only the appropriate binding strength of catalytic system exhibits the best catalytic activity. Modifying the type of coordination atoms could regulate the binding strength between the metal active center and the intermediate well, thus improving the catalytic performance of the system. 4 Conclusion In this work, we systematically investigated the performance of TM anchored Pc monolayers with and without different heteroatoms in the coordinating atoms as potential CRR catalysts by first-principles calculations (TM-Pc and TM-X-Pc, TM = Sc-Zn, X = B, C, N, O, and S), respectively. Evaluating the stability of the systems based on the formation energy (Ef) and dissolution potential (Udiss), in which Sc-B-Pc, Ti-B-Pc, Sc-Pc, and S heteroatom modified systems (TM-S-Pc) were excluded due to poor stability. Subsequently, we investigated and analyzed the CRR catalytic performance of the remaining 27 candidates, and the calculations indicated that Cr-Pc, Mn-Pc, Sc-O-Pc, Cr-O-Pc, Mn-O-Pc, Fe-O-Pc, and Co-O-Pc exhibited excellent catalytic performance for the generation of CH4, with the RDS all below 0.5 eV. The research on the activity origin of the system revealed that Eb(*OH) and Eb(*CHO) could serve as descriptors for the catalytic performance of the TM-X-Pc catalysts, displaying a linear relationship with the binding energy Eb of the oxygen- or carbon-bonded intermediates, and an activity volcano diagram with ΔG of the several reaction steps. In addition, the linear fitting results of Eb(*CHO) and UL(CH4) also present a volcano-type curve. Finally, the influence of the type of coordination atoms on the catalytic activity of the active center was analyzed by comparing the catalytic performance of TM-C-Pc, TM-O-Pc, TM-Pc and TM-S-Pc. The results suggest that modifying the type of coordination atoms could regulate the binding strength between the active center and the adsorbed intermediate, thus tune the catalytic performance of the system to reach the optimal CRR performance. Compared with TM-Pc, the O heteroatom modification in TM-O-Pc provide with the best coordinating environment for anchored TM, achieve the suitable binding strength for *CO and *CHO (weaker binding strength for *CO and stronger binding with *CHO). This can thus reduce the energy barrier for * CO → * CHO , leading to the RDS being other protonation step, and finally reaching the best catalytic activity. In summary, our research results show that TM-X-Pc monolayers can work as highly efficient CRR catalysts and provide theoretical guidance for experimental designing of CRR catalysis. coredata.dc:description: Developing of low cost and highly efficient electrocatalysts for carbon dioxide reduction (CRR) is becoming a research hotspot in both theoretical and experimental studies. In this work, we systematically investigated by first-principles calculations the electrocatalytic properties of transition-metal-anchored Phthalocyanine (Pc) monolayers with and without different heteroatom modifications, named TM-Pc and TM-X-Pc (TM = Sc∼ Zn, X = B, C, N, O, and S), respectively. The results show Cr-Pc, Mn-Pc, Sc-O-Pc, Cr-O-Pc, Mn-O-Pc, Fe-O-Pc, and Co-O-Pc exhibited excellent catalytic performance and high selectivity for CRR. The origin of catalytic activity analysis indicated the binding energy of intermediates Eb(*OH) and Eb(*CHO) serve as the descriptors for the catalytic performance of TM-X-Pc. Further comparative analyses showed that choosing appropriate coordination atoms is beneficial for adjusting the catalytic activity. The work suggests that the heteroatoms modified TM-X-Pc monolayer has high potential application as high-performance CRR catalyst and provides valuable theoretical guidance for designing efficient CRR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Coordination environment engineering of transition metal doped phthalocyanine single-atom catalysts for carbon dioxide reduction reaction: A DFT study
